**G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, § 4**, which vests original jurisdiction of civil actions exceeding $25,000 in the Superior Court.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, to establish negligence, a plaintiff must show **(1)** the existence of a duty of reasonable care, **(2)** a breach of that duty, **(3)** causation, and **(4)** damages. *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim under Massachusetts law, listing duty, breach, damages, and causation. Although the order is expressed as duty, breach, damage, and causal relation, this is substantively the same four-element formulation described in the proposition, and it is given as a general statement of Massachusetts negligence law, not limited to the facts of the case.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.relevant_excerpt: “3. Negligence claim, a. Duty of care, generally. To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. See J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005).”

**M.G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 155\u20131.proposition: Defendant owed a duty under **Massachusetts common law** and **M.G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–157**, as well as municipal regulations of Newton, to control his dog and prevent foreseeable harm to others.

See *Glidden v. Szybiak*, 368 Mass. 800,.raw_text: See *Glidden v. Szybiak*, 368 Mass. 800, 803 (1975) (dog owners have duty to prevent harm caused by their animals).
See *Glidden v. Szybiak*, 368 Mass. 800,.proposition: A reasonable person under like circumstances would have ensured that the dog remained leashed and under physical control at all times. See *Glidden v. Szybiak*, 368 Mass. 800, 803 (1975) (dog owners have duty to prevent harm caused by their animals).
See *Glidden v. Szybiak*, 368 Mass. 800,.case_name: Boston Gas Co. v. Department of Public Utilities
See *Glidden v. Szybiak*, 368 Mass. 800,.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a lengthy public-utilities/rate-making decision involving Boston Gas Company and the Department of Public Utilities; it does not concern dog ownership, animal control, or negligence standards for handling dogs. The proposition about a reasonable person keeping a dog leashed and owners’ duties to prevent harm from their animals is unrelated to the subject matter or holdings of this case. The citation to Glidden v. Szybiak is also incorrect both in case name/topic and page context for this text.
See *Glidden v. Szybiak*, 368 Mass. 800,.relevant_excerpt: This opinion contains no discussion of dogs, animals, or owners’ duties regarding them. Its focus is on gas utility rate proceedings, weather adjustments, rate base calculations, and related constitutional and administrative law issues.

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s*, 423 Mass. 6.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s*, 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996) (foreseeability central to proximate cause).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s*, 423 Mass. 6.proposition: It was foreseeable that an unleashed, barking dog charging at a pedestrian could cause fear and evasive action resulting in injury. *Poskus v. Lombardo’s*, 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996) (foreseeability central to proximate cause).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s*, 423 Mass. 6.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s*, 423 Mass. 6.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Poskus v. Lombardo’s is a concurrence focused on proximate cause and foreseeability in the context of keys left in ignitions, not dog attacks. It does not discuss dogs, pedestrians, or injuries resulting from evasive action taken in fear of an animal. While the case may address foreseeability generally, this text does not provide authority for the specific proposition about an unleashed, barking dog causing fear and evasive action injuries.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s*, 423 Mass. 6.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: Plaintiff’s fall and resulting fractured wrist are a **natural and probable consequence** of Defendant’s negligence. *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses foreseeability and proximate cause in terms of whether the plaintiff’s injury was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligence in leaving the forklift unsecured, but it does not specifically characterize a fall and fractured wrist or any similar specific injury as the "natural and probable consequence" of the negligence. The court speaks in terms of foreseeability of harm to persons in the area and that the injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible, not in the more particularized way stated in the proposition. Thus the citation overstates and slightly mischaracterizes the holding.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen who the authority knew had unfettered access to the cargo area. It was also reasonably foreseeable, because of the complexity of the operation of such a dangerous machine, that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area, such as those visiting the ships. … Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.

*M.G.L. c. 140, \u00a7 173*.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was in violation of *M.G.L. c. 140, § 173* (municipal control of dogs and enforcement of leash laws) and Newton’s municipal leash ordinance.

*M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85*.proposition: Under *M.G.L. c. 231, § 85*, the comparative negligence statute, Plaintiff was not negligent and bears no fault for her injuries.

*Sena v. Commonwealth*, 417 Mass. 250, 2.proposition: Plaintiff suffered lost income, physical pain, mental anguish, and loss of enjoyment of life. *Sena v. Commonwealth*, 417 Mass. 250, 256 (1994).
*Sena v. Commonwealth*, 417 Mass. 250, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion describes the plaintiffs’ embarrassment, inconvenience, and pecuniary expense, but it does not state that they suffered lost income, physical pain, mental anguish, or loss of enjoyment of life, nor does it discuss those categories of damages as part of the court’s holding. The cited page concerns the nature of the governmental discretionary function and briefly characterizes the plaintiffs’ injury in general terms, not in the detailed damage categories asserted in the proposition. Therefore, this case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Sena v. Commonwealth*, 417 Mass. 250, 2.relevant_excerpt: “The injury suffered by the plaintiffs — embarrassment, inconvenience, and pecuniary expense — while not insubstantial, cannot be wholly unexpected in our unavoidably imperfect system of law enforcement.” *Sena v. Commonwealth*, 417 Mass. 250, 259 (1994).

*Coughlin v. The Bldg. Comm\u2019r of Ca.raw_text: *Coughlin v. The Bldg. Comm’r of Cambridge*, 364 Mass. 51 (1973) – responsibility for foreseeable risks.
*Coughlin v. The Bldg. Comm\u2019r of Ca.proposition: *Coughlin v. The Bldg. Comm’r of Cambridge*, 364 Mass. 51 (1973) – responsibility for foreseeable risks.
*Coughlin v. The Bldg. Comm\u2019r of Ca.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is In re Troy, a judicial discipline case, not Coughlin v. Building Commissioner of Cambridge. It concerns judicial misconduct, bail practices, misuse of court personnel, and related issues, and does not analyze tort or regulatory principles of responsibility for foreseeable risks. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for the proposition attributed to Coughlin regarding responsibility for foreseeable risks.

*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.raw_text: *Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass. 362 (1980) – negligence elements and causation.
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.proposition: *Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 Mass. 362 (1980) – negligence elements and causation.
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Griffin focuses on evidentiary rulings, jury instructions on damages (future earning capacity, interest, and income taxes), and review of an allegedly excessive verdict. It does not set out or analyze the elements of negligence or articulate a general rule of causation; causation is only implicit in the factual dispute between experts. Accordingly, this case, at least as reflected in the quoted sections, is not authority for a general proposition about negligence elements and causation.
*Griffin v. General Motors Corp.*, 380 M.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff’s experts testified that the negligent design of the hood and fresh air system permitted fumes from a gasoline leak in the engine compartment to enter the passenger compartment, and that those fumes were ignited when the plaintiff activated her lighter. The resulting flames flashed back to the source of the fumes in the engine compartment and then burned with high intensity through the vent she had opened. The defendant’s expert testified that gasoline fumes could not travel from the engine compartment into the passenger compartment..."

*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.raw_text: *Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (1988) – breach of duty evaluated by reasonable-person standard.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.proposition: *Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (1988) – breach of duty evaluated by reasonable-person standard.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines negligence using an ordinary/reasonable-person formulation and then frames the dispositive question as whether an "ordinarily prudent person" in the defendant’s position would have taken additional precautions. The court’s analysis repeatedly applies this reasonable-person/ordinarily prudent person standard to determine breach of duty, thereby squarely supporting the proposition that breach is evaluated under a reasonable-person standard.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Negligence, without qualification and in its ordinary sense, is the failure of a responsible person…to exercise that degree of care…which, in the discharge of the duty then resting on him, the person of ordinary caution and prudence ought to exercise under the particular circumstances. … Ordinarily, where a duty of care is established by law, the standard by which a party’s performance is measured is the conduct expected of an ordinarily prudent person in similar circumstances. … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that…an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps…to prevent the accident that occurred.”

*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.raw_text: *Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 Mass. 37 (2009) – damages in negligence actions.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.proposition: *Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 Mass. 37 (2009) – damages in negligence actions.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.support_reasoning: The case is primarily about duty and proximate cause (scope of liability) in negligence, not a general treatment of damages in negligence actions. While the opinion recites the standard negligence elements, including that damage must result, it does not substantively analyze or set any rule about how damages are measured or awarded. Citing this case broadly for the proposition 'damages in negligence actions' is therefore inaccurate or at best overly generic.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on his negligence claims, Leavitt must prove that the hospital owed him a duty of reasonable care, that the hospital committed a breach of that duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of duty and the damage." 454 Mass. at 40.

**M.G.L. c. 261, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Award costs of this action pursuant to **M.G.L. c. 261, § 1**, and such other relief as justice and equity may require;

**M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: Award pre- and post-judgment interest under **M.G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
